text: The Type I and Type IUstations have a duplicated master oscillator and one spare synthesizer (as a compromise between full redundancy and economy) for the three operational local oscillator sources (receive, PN, and FM transmit). 15.4.2 Type III and IV Earth Terminals The SKYNET Types I and IV earth terminals have 6-meter (21-foot) diameter antennas. Both types of stations are identical, but the Type IVis helicopter trans­ portable, whereas the Type III is only transportable by standard aircraft. A simpli­ fied block diagram of the signal paths in the Type II and IV earth terminal is shown in Figure 15-7(5)(6). A five-horn static split system is used for tracking, and all the microvave equipment is mounted on the back of the antenna disk. The antenna mount is a simple two-axis elevation/azimuth system. The received signals pass through a diplexer and a band-stop filter to reject transmitted frequencies, and then into a two-stage liquid nitrogen-cooled parametric amplifier. Subsequently, they pass to a mixer/IF preamp combination and then to an IF amplifier where the FDM and spread spectrum signals are separated.
